comment_regular_data.body:
Thank you so much, @bfredl!

It does seem like it fixes the culprit of #26372, i.e. with `nvim --clean -u NORC --cmd 'call system(["sleep", "1"])' --cmd 'color blue'` background stays the same as it was before. And adding a `redraw` before sleep does show the proper data.

One thing I noticed is that setting `termguicolors` results into showing `#000000` background for me. I.e. `nvim --clean -u NORC --cmd 'set termguicolors' --cmd 'call system(["sleep", "1"])'` will show black background for a second and then show the new default color scheme. It would be good to make it work as `notermguicolors`, but I can see it being in the same realm as `redraw` for this use case.
Can confirm this avoids the flicker for me.

I've just retried it and it doesn't seem to work well with `termguicolors` (like in [this comment](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/26381#issuecomment-1838192503)). With `termguicolors` becoming default for terminal emulators that support it, this isn't really fixing #26372. Am I missing something?

I just chose to take one step at a time as I wasn't sure if termguicolors by default was decided yet, and this by itself fixes the issue for a lot of users so no reason to delay this PR. 

Will do a similar fix for the termguicolors event as a follow up.

I'm not sure whether this is expected, but the flash still appears when I use neovim for man pages. (I.e., `MANPAGER=nvim +Man!`.)

I mention it only because I thought this fix removed the flash both when starting neovim normally and when running, e.g., `man nvim`, but now the flash is back for man pages.

@telemachus You're seeing the same thing that @echasnovski [pointed out](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/26381#issuecomment-1843533157). You can reproduce this with `nvim --cmd 'sleep 1'`. The `:Man` command does some nontrivial pre-processing which takes just long enough to make the "flash" visible. @bfredl already mentioned that a fix for `'termguicolors'` will be a follow up.
@gpanders Thanks for clarifying. I thought that might be what was happening, but I wasn't sure what the `:Man` command did.
@telemachus Can you try testing again on master with https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/26579 to see if you can still reproduce the issue?

@gpanders Thanks for the ping. Unfortunately, I still have the same issue.

https://github.com/neovim/neovim/assets/62958/fffb9dd8-d209-4866-ae62-0ba6742158e1

In case it helps, here are some details.

+ nvim: NVIM v0.10.0-dev-1855+g0d26d192d
+ colorscheme: A fork of [github-nvim-theme](https://github.com/telemachus/github-nvim-theme)
+ terminal: Ghostty cc6270f
+ os: macOS 14.2
+ Relevant (maybe?) bit of my `init.lua`:

    ```lua
    opt.termguicolors = true
    opt.background = "light"
    
    -- https://github.com/telemachus/github-nvim-theme
    local theme_loaded = safe_setup("github-theme", {
        theme_style = "light",
        sidebars = { "qf", "lf" },
        comment_style = "NONE",
        keyword_style = "NONE",
        function_style = "NONE",
        variable_style = "NONE",
        hide_end_of_buffer = false,
        hide_inactive_statusline = false,
        dark_float = true,
        dark_sidebar = true,
        transparent = true,
        overrides = function(c)
            return {
                Conceal = { fg = c.fg },
            }
        end,
    })
    if theme_loaded then
        cmd("colorscheme github_light")
    else
        cmd("colorscheme off")
    end
    ```

> Try removing `opt.termguicolors = true`.

No joy. I commented out both `opt.termguicolors = true` and `opt.background = "light"`, but I get the same black flash.

**Edit**: removing `termguicolors` does fix things, but I had to remove the setting *both* from my startup files and from the colorscheme I was using. Sorry that I didn't think of this earlier.

title: fix(startup): only send one default_colors_set event during startup
